title: 106_hr4584
content: The Act is titled the "Affordable Transaction Account Act" and aims to provide affordable banking services. The "Affordable Transaction Account Act" requires insured depository institutions to offer affordable consumer transaction accounts with specific features determined by federal banking agencies, including limits on initial deposits, minimum balances, and a minimum number of free withdrawals. The "Affordable Transaction Account Act" mandates insured depository institutions to provide affordable consumer transaction accounts with specific features, including limits on initial deposits and minimum balances. Additionally, institutions can charge a reasonable fee for withdrawal transactions exceeding the minimum number of free withdrawals. The Affordable Transaction Account Act requires insured depository institutions to offer affordable consumer transaction accounts with specific features and limits on fees and charges. The amount of fees imposed on these accounts cannot exceed what is normally applied to other consumer transaction accounts at the institution. The Affordable Transaction Account Act mandates insured depository institutions to provide affordable transaction accounts with certain conditions for opening and maintaining the account. Residents of the state where the account is held must be the account holder, and recurring payments like Social Security must be made through direct deposit. Other terms and conditions apply, but fees cannot exceed those of other consumer transaction accounts at the institution. The Affordable Transaction Account Act requires insured depository institutions to offer affordable transaction accounts with specific conditions. Fees for services not related to account maintenance must not exceed those of other consumer accounts at the institution. An insured depository institution is not obligated to offer an affordable transaction account if the individual already has another consumer account with the same or a different institution. Alternatively, the institution can provide a different account or banking services approved by the Federal banking agency. Disclosure requirements include posting notices about available consumer transaction options. The depository institution must post notices about the availability of consumer transaction accounts and affordable transaction accounts in a public area. Printed material describing other consumer transaction accounts must also include information about affordable transaction accounts. Definitions for "consumer transaction account" are provided in this section. The term "consumer transaction account" refers to various transaction accounts used for personal, family, or household purposes. Definitions for "depository institution," "Federal banking agency," and "insured depository institution" are also provided in this section. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act defines an insured credit union. If a depository institution operates in a state with more stringent laws on affordable transaction accounts, it must comply with both state and federal requirements to be considered a qualified depository institution. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act requires depository institutions to comply with state laws on affordable transaction accounts in addition to federal requirements. Federal laws do not preempt state laws mandating affordable transaction accounts for depository institutions.
